s.text: The NYT lead reports that according to the General Accounting Office, only one-third of the 421 computer systems used nationwide for the major health, welfare and nutrition benefit programs are ready for the year 2000.

The NYT lead reports that according to the General Accounting Office, only one-third of the 421 computer systems used nationwide for the major health, welfare and nutrition benefit programs are ready for the year 2000.

The NYT lead reports that according to the General Accounting Office, only one-third of the 421 computer systems used nationwide for the major health, welfare and nutrition benefit programs are ready for the year 2000.

The NYT lead reports that according to the General Accounting Office, only one-third of the 421 computer systems used nationwide for the major health, welfare and nutrition benefit programs are ready for the year 2000.

The New York Times leads with word that because most states are behind schedule in their attempts to eliminate Y2K problems from their computer systems, it's likely that some people receiving welfare and other anti-poverty benefits will have their payments and/or services interrupted.
The paper explains why Japan is hesitant to go further than this: it fears Chinese demands for compensatory damages.
Despite the revelations, the co-chairman of the Senate Y2K committee definitely sees a glass half full: "There aren't as many people lying to us as there used to be."
